pageData.text: Microorganisms live in a wide variety of environments and are able to utilize a range of nutrient sources. In order to utilize the available food sources and cope with hostile environments, microorganisms have developed specialized <button class='glossary-text'>biochemical pathways</button>. Researchers and healthcare professionals use these specific pathways to identify unknown microbes through biochemical techniques. In this investigation, three of the most commonly used techniques will be employed to characterize bacteria.

pageData.text:
As of 2022, there were an estimated 14 million pounds (about 6,350,288 kg) of plastic waste in our oceans1. Most of these plastics are not biodegradable and so cannot be converted back into useable organic material through normal processes. These plastics can harm sea life, catching in gills of fish or strangling marine mammals. Additionally, many of these plastics break down into microplastics which can be ingested by organisms of all sizes and have even been found in human blood samples. Once these plastics enter the oceans, they are extremely difficult and costly to remove.Enter the bacteria Ideonella sakaiensis with its unique . I. sakaiensis contains an enzyme, PETase, which allows it to break down the common plastic polyethylene terephthalate (PET). These bacteria can convert PET into simple hydrocarbons that they then metabolize as a food source. Scientists are still working on how to translate this metabolic pathway into a strategy against large-scale plastic pollution in the oceans, but it provides a possible biological solution to a challenging problem1.1Dutfield, S. (2022, March 23).Plastic-eating bacteria: Genetic Engineering and Environmental impact.
LiveScience. https://www.livescience.com/plastic-eating-bacteria

pageData.text: Microbes live everywhere in our environment, which requires them to cope with a wide variety of nutritional sources such as different simple and complex protein structures. The environment can also be extremely hostile, and in order to survive, microbes have adjusted their <button class='glossary-text'>biochemical pathways</button>. These pathways allow them to utilize nutritional sources other organisms are unable to use, which may give the adapted microbes a competitive advantage over other species. In addition, these bacteria can modify their pathways to break down harmful substances in their environment, allowing them to survive under very specific conditions. However, not all microbe species or groups have developed similar biochemical pathways; most are extremely specific. This specificity can be used to isolate and identify the different microbes.

Selective and differential media, Gram staining, and other similar techniques are reliable methods for initial identification and isolation of microbes. Unfortunately, these techniques are not very specific and cannot isolate or identify microbes from a group of similar microbes. For example, Gram staining allows for quick identification of bacteria with limited or extended peptidoglycan layers, but this identification encompasses a wide variety of microbes. In order to achieve a higher level of specificity, these techniques can be used in a step-wise manner; first, a Gram stain is performed to identify Gram-negative microbes.

These microbes are then plated on MacConkey agar, which is used to identify microbes able to ferment lactose. If this technique does not sufficiently decrease the number of microbe species present in order to identify one species, another technique can then be used to further identify the bacterial species.

Biochemical tests do take time, microbial growth is required to detect the changes caused by the biochemical products. In the healthcare and food industries, however, more rapid identification is needed. This need has led companies to develop quick tests that perform approximately 20 different biochemical tests on one sample in a very short period of time. Most of these tests include a reference guide to quickly read and identify the type of microbes present.
In this investigation, the following standard biochemical tests will be used to identify bacterial species.

pageData.subTitle: Catalase
pageData.text: Hydrogen peroxide is sometimes used as a cleaner and disinfectant, because it is damaging to most microorganisms. However, some bacteria have developed an enzyme called , which converts hydrogen peroxide into harmless water and oxygen. In order to test for the presence of bacteria which possess catalase, a drop of hydrogen peroxide is mixed with bacteria. If the bacteria contain catalase, oxygen bubbles can be observed (see Figure 1).

pageData.subTitle: Oxidase
pageData.text: During , oxygen is used to accept electrons from the electron transport chain in the terminal biochemical reaction of respiration. In most organisms, this is accomplished by the enzyme cytochrome c . However, some bacterial species have developed alternative methods to transport the electrons out of the respiratory reaction. In this part of the investigation, the presence of oxidase will be determined by adding a few drops of an oxidase reagent to bacteria on a piece of filter paper. If the bacteria possess cytochrome c oxidase, the filter paper will turn purple (see Figure 2).

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Close-up photos of bacterial growth from two different organisms with oxidase reagent applied. The one on the left has not changed color and thus is oxidase-negative; the one on the right has turned dark bluish-purple and is therefore oxidase-positive.

pageData.subTitle: Triple Sugar Iron (TSI) Medium
pageData.text: Some bacteria use <button class='glossary-text'>fermentation</button> of chemicals, such as sugars, as an energy source, which produces acid by-products. <button class='glossary-text'>TSI medium</button> contains a small amount of glucose, a high amount of lactose, a high amount of sucrose, proteins to provide carbon and nitrogen, as well as low concentrations of ferrous sulfate, sodium thiosulfate, and a pH indicator, phenol red. The pH indicator will change color under different pH conditions.

Bacteria use glucose as their preferred energy source, but as the glucose is depleted, bacteria that are unable to ferment either lactose or sucrose will need to break down proteins for energy. This will result in the production of ammonia, which will raise the pH around the bacteria, as indicated by a red or purple color. In contrast, organisms able to ferment lactose or sucrose will lower the pH, resulting in a yellow color. Fermentation often produces gas as a by-product, as evidenced by bubbles in the agar surrounding the microbial growth.

Sometimes hydrogen sulfide gas, identified by its rotten-egg smell, is produced during fermentation. Hydrogen sulfide then reacts with the ferrous sulfate and causes a black <button class='glossary-text'>precipitate</button> to form. Bacteria use <button class='glossary-text'>anaerobic respiration</button> (not the same as fermentation) with thiosulfate (present in the TSI medium) as the terminal electron acceptor. The thiosulfate anion is reduced to hydrogen sulfide, which then reacts with the ferrous sulfate to form ferrous sulfide (the black precipitate you see).

For this part of the investigation, tubes of TSI medium will be inoculated with bacteria to determine if the bacteria are fermenters and producers of hydrogen sulfide. A range of different reactions are possible, as shown in Figure 3 and <button class='resource-text'>Table 1</button>.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Photo of five TSI slants. The slant is the upper portion of the agar in each tube, with a large surface area to be inoculated and exposed to the air in the tube during incubation. The butt is the bottom portion of the agar in each tube, and has no surface area available for inoculation or air exposure. From left to right, the tubes are: uninoculated control with the original TSI color in the slant and butt; no marked color change in slant or butt scored as NC; black precipitate in slant and butt with upward displacement of the agar scored A/A, G, H2S, red slant and yellow butt with upward displacement of the agar scored as K/A, G; yellow slant and yellow butt scored as A/A.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. To prepare, disinfect the work surface, prepare a disposal jar, light the candle and prepare bacterial cultures. In activity 1, prepare the TSI medium slants, inoculate them with the bacteria and incubate. Next, observe the slants after 24, 48 and 72 hours and record your observations. If no color appears, record it as oxidase-negative. In activity 3, divide and label the glass slides. Then, transfer bacterial growth to a slide section and add hydrogen peroxide. Finally, check for bubbles. If no bubbles appear, record it as catalase-negative. If bubbles do appear, record it as catalase-positive.

pageData.text: Label each slant tube with the name of each bacterium: E. coli, S. epidermidis, and M. luteus.

To inoculate the tube of TSI medium, stab the loop through the center of the medium to the very bottom of the butt as shown in Figure 4.The agar will reseal itself around the stab, creating anaerobic (without oxygen) conditions. Then, as you pull the loop out of the TSI medium, streak it back and forth across the surface of the slant. Place the loop in the disposal jar.

In Activity 3, you will treat bacterial samples with hydrogen peroxide to determine if the bacteria possess the enzyme <button class='glossary-text'>catalase</button>.
Draw a line down the center of each slide with the grease pencil or permanent marker. Label the slides as shown in Figure 6. The control half of the first slide will not receive any bacterial growth.

pageData.text: Using an inoculation loop, aseptically transfer a loop of E. coli growth from the tryptic soy agar E. coli slant to the surface of the E. coli half of the first slide. Place the used loop in the disposal jar.

Caution: Do not re-insert the inoculation loop into the E. coli culture. This is a break in aseptic technique that will result in contamination. If your transfer is not successful, try again with a new loop.
Repeat Step 2 for S. epidermidis and M. luteus, using a new loop for each. Place the used loops in the disposal jar.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Place the slides on a piece of dark paper. Carefully add one drop of hydrogen peroxide to the control area and each bacterial growth sample on both slides. Observe immediately for the development of bubbles. The control area should be free of bubbles. Take a picture and record your observations in Data Table 3.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: After the reaction has finished, carefully place the slides in the disposal jar along with the loops, and let everything sit for at least 30 minutes. Then wrap the slides in a paper towel secured with tape, and discard the slides and loops in the garbage.

To dispose of the used inoculating loops, filter paper pieces, and glass slides, soak them in the disposal jar with isopropyl alcohol for at least 30 minutes, then discard them in the garbage. When discarding the glass slides, wrap them in several layers of paper towel secured with a piece of adhesive tape. This will prevent the slides from hurting anyone handling the garbage should they break. Pour the alcohol down the drain with running water, and allow the water to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the alcohol.
Keep your tube cultures of E. coli, S. epidermidis, and M. luteus unless otherwise directed by your instructor. This includes the broth cultures and the tryptic soy agar slant cultures.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: To dispose of cultures that are no longer needed, put on your PPE, ensure adequate ventilation, and fill a container that is large enough to hold all the cultures with 10% bleach solution. While holding each tube or plate submerged in the bleach solution, open them, then allow the cultures to soak in the bleach for at least 24 hours.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: After 24 hours, put on your PPE and pour the bleach down the drain with running water, and allow the water to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the bleach. Place the disinfected tubes and plates in an opaque plastic bag, and discard in the garbage.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

The slant is the upper portion of the agar in each tube, with a large surface area to be inoculated and exposed to the air in the tube during incubation. From left to right, the tubes are: uninoculated control with the original TSI color in the slant and butt; no marked color change in slant or butt scored as NC; black precipitate in slant and butt with upward displacement of the agar scored A/A, G, H2S, red slant and yellow butt with upward displacement of the agar scored as K/A, G; yellow slant and yellow butt scored as A/A.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. To prepare, disinfect the work surface, prepare a disposal jar, light the candle and prepare bacterial cultures. In activity 1, prepare the TSI medium slants, inoculate them with the bacteria and incubate. Next, observe the slants after 24, 48 and 72 hours and record your observations. In activity 2, cut and label the filter paper. Then, inoculate the paper with bacterial growth and add oxidase reagent. Next, wait 10 seconds and check for purple color. If purple color appears, record it as oxidase-positive. If it does not appear, wait 60 seconds. If the color appears, record it as delayed oxidase-positive. If no color appears, record it as oxidase-negative. In activity 3, divide and label the glass slides. Then, transfer bacterial growth to a slide section and add hydrogen peroxide. Finally, check for bubbles. If no bubbles appear, record it as catalase-negative. If bubbles do appear, record it as catalase-positive.

data.title: Aerobic respiration
data.content: A type of cellular respiration in which oxygen is the final electron acceptor in the electron transport chain

data.title: Anaerobic respiration
data.content: A type of cellular respiration in which organic or inorganic molecules are used as final electron acceptors in the electron transport chain; this process involves the citric acid cycle and electron transport chain

data.title: Agglutination
data.content: The sticking together of cells into a clump or mass

data.title: Biochemical pathway
data.content: A series of enzyme-mediated reactions where the product of one reaction is the substrate for the subsequent reaction, and so on; also called a metabolic pathway

data.title: Catalase
data.content: An enzyme that breaks down hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen gas

data.title: Fermentation
data.content: A metabolic process that produces chemical changes in organic substrates through the action of enzymes in the absence of oxygen; it does not involve the citric acid cycle or electron transport chain

data.title: Oxidase
data.content: An enzyme that catalyzes oxidation-reduction reactions; also called cytochrome c oxidase

data.title: Precipitate
data.content: A substance separated from a solution or suspension due to a chemical or physical change as an insoluble solid

data.title: Bombay phenotype
data.content: A condition in which individuals do not express the H antigen

data.title: Triple sugar iron (TSI) medium
data.content: A bacterial growth medium that contains a small amount of glucose, a high amount of lactose, a high amount of sucrose, proteins to provide carbon and nitrogen, as well as low concentrations of ferrous sulfate, sodium thiosulfate, and a pH indicator (phenol red)
